Every time I return from Europe (which is three times), I get into religion. It happened again after Iceland. I found this book at Kroger's and read it, trying to make sense of God, Jesus and the Resurrection. 
 
 Who was Jesus? Was He both God and man? Were the miracles real? Is the Resurrection fact or fiction? 
 
 Jesus said, "I am the vine." He said, "I am the gate." He said, "I am the way, the truth and the life." 
 
 The life of Christ is told in four gospels. Mark's gospel came first. Mark knew Peter and wrote his gospel based on Peter's account. Peter was in Jesus' inner circle. 
 
 Mark's gospel influenced Matthew and Luke. Matthew was a disciple. Luke was Paul's physician. The first three gospels are similar. John emphasizes Jesus' deity. 
 
 The biographies of Jesus differ from modern biographies. Parts of Jesus' life are skimmed over or omitted. Matthew has ties with the Old Testament. Mark focuses on the last week of Jesus' life. Luke underscores His humanity. John presents Jesus as the preexistent Word made flesh. 
 
 Paul encountered Jesus on the road to Damascus. Paul's New Testament letters predate the gospels. He attests to Jesus being the Messiah who died for sins and rose from the grave. Paul writes that other people saw the resurrected Jesus. The idea is that Christ's followers will be resurrected as He was, that victory over death is achieved through faith. 
 
 Jesus' miracles took different forms. Some were psychosomatic like driving demons out of Mary Magdalene. Others showed power over nature like walking on water and turning water into wine. Jesus demonstrated His power over death by bringing Lazarus back to life. Colossians 1:16 states that Jesus created all things. He had power over all things. 
 
 Even more revealing is that Jesus forgave sinners. Such authority was associated with God. 
 
 What can we say about God? God is all-powerful, or omnipotent. He is everywhere, or omnipresent. He is all-knowing, or omniscient. He is eternal and infinite. He is the uncreated Creator. The New Testament implies that Jesus was all of these. 
 
 God is Spirit in the Old Testament. He is flesh in the New Testament. Jesus fulfilled 300 Old Testament prophecies. Zechariah 9:9 prophesied that He would enter Jerusalem on a donkey. 
 
 The seven days before Easter Sunday are called Passion (suffering) Week. Jesus rode into Jerusalem on Palm Sunday, had the Last Supper on Thursday and was crucified on Good Friday. Sinless Jesus bore the sins of all humanity. 
 
 What of the Resurrection? Did the disciples steal Jesus' body? If there was a Resurrection, was it physical or spiritual? The American Bible Society concedes that the Resurrection is unbelievable while "resonating with inner truth." 
 
 No one saw Jesus come back to life even though the Bible records post-Resurrection appearances. Jesus appeared to His disciples and to Mary Magdalene. He appeared to Peter and James. He appeared to Paul. He appeared to 500 people at once. 
 
 There are no appearances in Mark. Matthew and Luke have a few. John has the most. 
 
 Jesus ascended into heaven from the Mount of Olives. He sent The Holy Spirit. The Pentecost, a painting by Jean Restout, is reproduced. 
 
 If a Creator, responsible for the "surge of energy" which exploded as the Big Bang, suspended the laws of nature to manifest Himself or Itself in the space/time continuum, then the Incarnation, miracles and Resurrection are true. 
 
 The Resurrection is the cornerstone of Christianity. According to the Bible, we must believe to receive God's grace. It is then that we become children of God. 
 
 Do I believe? Of course! Hallelujah! Thank you! Jesus!! 
 Jesus Paid My Debt http://jimcolyer.com/@tracks/9/lofi.mp3

 What happens when I examine theses scriptures with an open mind is that I see huge gaps between what is purported as prophecy and fulfillment. The majority of these items are ambiguous at best, many have been shown to be out of context, inconsistent with the facts, or simply interjected in hindsight to make it look something that could fit into a prophecy-fulfillment format. 
 
 I'm sure you remember our exhaustive debate on how long jesus was dead in the biblical contradictions section. Matthew's interjection of the jonas comparison put that account into a lot of trouble. It wasn't a prophecy fulfillment at all, but rather evidence of overzealous religious writers trying to invent prophecies where none existed to make their case for messiah better, when in fact it does nothing but add to the skepticism of the truly open minded. 
 
 The truth is that in order to accept this list of prophecy-fulfillments, you'd actually have to be already convinced and mentally predisposed to accept the bible as true and infallible, regardless of the pile of inconsistencies and ambiguities therein. An open-minded person would see this list objectively and have the hardest time buying it. 
 
 By the way, I'm still curious to hear jim colyer expand on his thoughts of the big bang and the impact removing genesis would have on christianity.

And you will understand that it isn't God punishing you forever; you will clearly see all of the times He placed people like me in before you to share the truth which you spent a lifetime responding to as you have right now.  And I am only one messenger of many. By no means am I special. But like all believers, we realize that what we have received is more precious than pure gold and it is the only gift worth sharing when all is said and done in life. Eternity is forever after all, this life is nothing more than a wisp of wind. I understand how you feel though, and i'm sorry you're willing to risk eternal security by denying what is so freely offered in a spirit of unconditional love.
 
 You say, Certainly if God exists I may have to account for my behavior, what you fail to understand is that nothing you can do either now or then can cover up or account for your sins. That's why Jesus had to take the sins of man upon Himself in order to sanctify and purify us. I am saved not because of anything I have done, but because of what Jesus did. And you're right that I too am a sinner who is by no means perfect just because I'm saved. But I've been washed because of what He did, and not because of my own merit at all. I just want that to be clear to you so that you wont think that you're going to be having some meeting with God where these issues will be discussed and debated. Here's how Jesus put it.
 Jhn 10:3 The watchman opens the gate for him, and the sheep listen to his voice. He calls his own sheep by name and leads them out.
 
 Jhn 10:4 When he has brought out all his own, he goes on ahead of them, and his sheep follow him because they know his voice.
 
 Jhn 10:5 But they will never follow a stranger; in fact, they will run away from him because they do not recognize a stranger's voice."
 
 Jhn 10:6 Jesus used this figure of speech, but they did not understand what he was telling them.
 
 Jhn 10:7 Therefore Jesus said again, "I tell you the truth, I am the gate for the sheep.
 
 Jhn 10:8 All who ever came before me were thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not listen to them.
 
 Jhn 10:9 I am the gate; whoever enters through me will be saved. [fn] He will come in and go out, and find pasture.
 
 Jhn 10:10 The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy; I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full.
 
 Jhn 10:11 "I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.

By Unkerpaulie
 You wouldn't happen to have a link that lists these 300 fulfilled prophecies, now would you? Through past discussions on this forum we have discovered a few inconsistencies within the gospels, particularly as it relates to mentioned prophecies that are supposed to be fulfilled. 
 
 The other thing about your post that strikes my attention is that you mention the big bang. Would that mean that you don't subscribe to a 7-day creation as described in genesis? Some important underlying concepts that are established in the genesis creation story: God is all powerful, and man is sinful and in need of redemption. If you remove the genesis story, how do you reconcile these two critical foundations of christianity?
 
 Other than that, interesting post. I think there's potential for a good discussion here.
 
 
 
 
 hey Unkerpaulie
 A number of fulfilled prophecies are listed in the book, The Life of Christ. I do not have them with me now. I know that in Psalm 22, David supposedly has a vision of Christ on the cross. I think all the prophecies are very flimsy and open to interpretation. Yet they may all be true. I have wrestled with science and religion for a long time, trying to reconcile the two in my own mind. It is hard to accept 7-day creation as anything but poetic mythology. Yet there is always a grain of truth even in mythology. The Big Bang is accepted by science as real. Perhaps certain aspects of the Genesis story can be fit into the ideas of modern science like God's omnipotence and man's fall and need for redemption. The book I reviewed did not touch on a second coming of Jesus, but I have entertained the notion that if the universe is 13.7 billion years old and in middle age, Jesus might return in another 13.7 billion years. At that time, he might harvest souls in other galaxies or parallel universes if they exist. 
 Jim

 Now, if you read Pslam 22 in context, it has nothing to do with Jesus what so ever. Mind you, the words were used by the unknown author of the 'Gospel of Matthew', but using the words later on is not a prophecy of Jesus 1000 years later.
 
 The literary device that attempts to compare Jesus and David does not mean there is a prophecy in the Psalms

I agree that it is a stretch to relate Bible prophecies of the Old Testament to events which took place in the New. Perhaps if you took all the prophecies out of context and laid them on the table, they would form some vague sketch of Jesus as the Christ and Messiah.
